authors.name: Huang Zongxi
authors.description: Leading philosopher and political thinker of the Ming-Qing transition. Author of the first systematic history of Chinese philosophy.

authors.name: Ji Yun
authors.description: Chief editor of the Siku Quanshu and powerful literary official. Wrote supernatural tales in a deliberately terse classical style.

authors.name: Li Baichuan
authors.description: Author of one of the great mid-Qing novels blending Daoist cultivation with political intrigue.

authors.name: Xia Jingqu
authors.description: Author of the longest pre-modern Chinese novel at 154 chapters.

authors.name: Li Lüyuan
authors.description: Author of a major Qing educational novel rediscovered only in the 20th century.

authors.name: Yu Wanchun
authors.description: Author of the anti-Water Margin sequel praised by Lu Xun for its literary quality.

authors.name: Shi Yukun
authors.description: Storyteller whose oral performances became the foundational Chinese martial-arts and detective novel.

authors.name: Zeng Pu
authors.description: Author of one of the four great novels of the late Qing, a roman à clef of diplomacy and scandal.

authors.name: Wu Xuan
authors.description: Author of a historical novel about the founding of the Song dynasty.

authors.name: Lü Xiong
authors.description: Author of a fantastical novel blending historical events with Daoist supernatural elements.

authors.name: Zhang Chao
authors.description: Literary arbiter and anthologist of the finest late Ming and early Qing tales.

authors.name: Zhang Nanzhuang
authors.description: Author of the first novel written in Wu dialect, championed by Lu Xun.

authors.name: Wu Zimu
authors.description: Author of a detailed record of life in Southern Song Hangzhou.

authors.name: Zhou Mi
authors.description: Leading literatus of the Song-Yuan transition. Prolific writer of biji recording the vanished world of Southern Song Hangzhou.

authors.name: Luo Dajing
authors.description: Song dynasty biji writer covering poetry criticism, history, and philosophy.

texts.title: Records of Ming Scholars (Mingru Xuean)
texts.description: The first systematic history of philosophy in any language. Huang Zongxi traces the development of Confucian thought through the entire Ming dynasty, school by school.

texts.title: Random Jottings at the Cottage of Close Scrutiny (Yuewei Caotang Biji)
texts.description: The greatest collection of supernatural tales by China's most powerful literary official. Ji Yun deliberately wrote in a classical, sparse style as a counterpoint to Pu Songling's ornate Liaozhai. Contains ~1,200 stories of wit, moral commentary, and ghost stories.

texts.title: Legendary Tale of the Green Wilds (Luye Xianzong)
texts.description: Ranked alongside Honglou Meng and Rulin Waishi as a great mid-Qing novel. Blends Daoist cultivation, political intrigue, and romance during the Ming Jiajing era.

texts.title: An Old Rustic's Idle Talk (Yesou Puyan)
texts.description: The longest pre-modern Chinese novel at 154 chapters. Follows scholar Wen Suchen through examinations, romances, and military campaigns in an encyclopedic narrative.

texts.title: Lamp at the Crossroads (Qilu Deng)
texts.description: A major Qing educational novel about a scholar's son squandering his inheritance. Only rediscovered in the 20th century; no complete English translation exists.

texts.title: Pacifying the Bandits (Dangkou Zhi)
texts.description: Anti-Water Margin sequel where the Liangshan outlaws are portrayed as villains. Lu Xun praised its literary quality despite its reactionary ideology.

texts.title: Three Heroes and Five Gallants (Sanxia Wuyi)
texts.description: The foundational Chinese martial-arts and detective novel combining Judge Bao courtroom drama with wuxia heroics. Source for countless later adaptations.

texts.title: A Flower in a Sea of Sin (Niehai Hua)
texts.description: A major roman à clef of late Qing diplomacy, politics, and scandal. Only 5 chapters translated into English (1982). One of the four great novels of the late Qing.

texts.title: Complete Tale of the Flying Dragon (Feilong Quanzhuan)
texts.description: Historical novel about the founding of the Song dynasty by Zhao Kuangyin (Emperor Taizu). A classic of dynastic-founding fiction.

texts.title: Unofficial History of the Female Immortals (Nuxian Waishi)
texts.description: Fantastical novel set during the Yongle Emperor's usurpation, blending historical events with Daoist supernatural elements and female warrior protagonists.

texts.title: New Records of Yu Chu (Yuchu Xinzhi)
texts.description: Anthology of the finest literary Chinese tales from the late Ming and early Qing, curated by one of the period's foremost literary arbiters.

texts.title: What Canon? (Hedian)
texts.description: The first novel written in Wu dialect (Shanghainese). A satirical ghost-world picaresque championed by Lu Xun and Hu Shi during the New Culture Movement.

texts.title: Record of the Millet Dream (Mengliang Lu)
texts.description: Detailed record of life in Southern Song Hangzhou modeled on the Dongjing Menghua Lu. Documents markets, crafts, festivals, and urban culture before the Mongol conquest.

texts.title: Past Events of Wulin (Wulin Jiushi)
texts.description: Zhou Mi's nostalgic record of Southern Song Hangzhou's court ceremonies, festivals, entertainments, and daily life before the Mongol conquest.

texts.title: Rustic Words from East of Qi (Qidong Yeyu)
texts.description: Zhou Mi's politically revealing biji covering Southern Song court politics, the Zhu Xi scandal, painting connoisseurship, and other historical anecdotes.

texts.title: Jade Dew from the Crane Forest (Helin Yulu)
texts.description: Song dynasty biji covering poetry criticism, historical anecdotes, philosophical discussions, and political commentary.
